Types


#


SubstitutionModels.NucleicAcidSubstitutionModel
 
 
Type
.


NucleicAcidSubstitutionModel
 is an abstract type that contains all models describing a substitution process impacting biological sequences of 
DNA
 or 
RNA
 with continous time Markov models.


source




Functions


#


SubstitutionModels.Q
 
 
Function
.


Generate a Q matrix for a 
NucleicAcidSubstitutionModel
, of the form:


math   Q =  egin{bmatrix}   Q_{A, A} 
 Q_{A, C} 
 Q_{A, G} 
 Q_{A, T} 
  Q_{C, A} 
 Q_{C, C} 
 Q_{C, G} 
 Q_{C, T} 
  Q_{G, A} 
 Q_{G, C} 
 Q_{G, G} 
 Q_{G, T} 
  Q_{T, A} 
 Q_{T, C} 
 Q_{T, G} 
 Q_{T, T} nd{bmatrix}.


source


#


SubstitutionModels.P
 
 
Function
.


Generate a P matrix for a 
NucleicAcidSubstitutionModel
, of the form:


math   P =  egin{bmatrix}   P_{A, A} 
 P_{A, C} 
 P_{A, G} 
 P_{A, T} 
  P_{C, A} 
 P_{C, C} 
 P_{C, G} 
 P_{C, T} 
  P_{G, A} 
 P_{G, C} 
 P_{G, G} 
 P_{G, T} 
  P_{T, A} 
 P_{T, C} 
 P_{T, G} 
 P_{T, T} nd{bmatrix}.


for specified time


source




Included models


Absolute and relative rate forms of the following popular substitution models are currently included in SubstitutionModels.jl:




JC69


K80


F81


F84


HKY85


TN93


GTR






Custom substitution models


The set of substitution models included in this package is easily extended with user defined types. When defining a new substitution model, the minimum requirement is that it is a subtype of 
NucleicAcidSubstitutionModel
, and that it has a valid method for the 
Q
 function. If a method for the 
P
 function for  a substitution model is not defined, P matrices will be calculated using the  matrix exponential as follows:


$$
P = \text{expm} \left(Q \times t \right).
$$


For many substitution models the P matrix has a known form. Rather than approximate and actually using julia's 
expm
 each time a P matrix required can be avoided by defining a method  for the 
P
 function, typically resulting in substantial computational savings.


A user defined substitution model may be described as a special case of the Generalized Time Reversible model (GTR), which has a Q matrix of the form:


$$
Q = \begin{bmatrix}
-(\delta \pi_{\text{C}} + \eta \pi_{\text{G}} + \beta \pi_{\text{T}}) 

\delta \pi_{\text{C}} 

\eta \pi_{\text{G}} 

\beta \pi_{\text{T}} \
\delta \pi_{\text{A}} 

-(\delta \pi_{\text{A}} + \epsilon \pi_{\text{G}} + \alpha \pi_{\text{T}}) 

\epsilon \pi_{\text{G}} 

\alpha \pi_{\text{T}} \
\eta \pi_{\text{A}} 

\epsilon \pi_{\text{C}} 

-(\eta \pi_{\text{A}} + \epsilon \pi_{\text{C}} + \gamma \pi_{\text{T}}) 

\gamma \pi_{\text{T}}) \
-(\beta \pi_{\text{A}} + \alpha \pi_{\text{C}} + \gamma \pi{\text{G}}) 

\beta \pi_{\text{A}} 

\alpha \pi_{\text{C}} 

\gamma \pi{\text{G}})
\end{bmatrix}.
$$


A new 
NucleicAcidSubstitutionModel
 may be described by defining a new method for each of the following internal functions: 
_α
, 
_β
, 
_γ
, 
_δ
, 
_ϵ
, and 
_η
. Additionally, if there are unequal base frequencies for this substitution model, methods for 
_πA
, 
_πC
, 
_πG
, and 
_πT
 will need to be defined.

SubstitutionModels.P


SubstitutionModels.Q
